executive_summary: Cable providers disseminate subscription video content from cable networks to consumers over wired telecommunications networks. In addition to video programming, these enterprises usually offer high-speed internet access and digital voice telephony services. These other services are frequently bundled in a single package with industry-relevant video services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic-induced disruptions hamstring industry revenue growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic harmed the cable providers industry in 2020. Despite per capita disposable income rising with increased stimulus given back to taxpayers, the resulting economic uncertainty contributed to the consumer confidence index falling exponentially, hurting the discretionary goods market.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The rise of streaming was bolstered by the pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise of streaming was bolstered by the pandemic, with many consumers at the time having to work from home to comply with social distancing guidelines, making internet-based expenses more of an essential cost.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry enterprises increasingly contend with cord-cutting
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the pandemic posed a challenging time for this industry, overall demand for cable TV subscriptions and the number of US cable TV subscriptions have plummeted. Cable subscription declines can be attributed to the rise of streaming services as consumers have gravitated to these services due to the vast types of content offered on these platforms.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Cable providers expand the scope of their offerings to bypass cable subscription declines
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although broadband is not included in revenue, it is often bundled with cable at a discount relative to standalone service prices. These deep customer relationships and upselling explain the industry's less dramatic decline compared with subscriber loss rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The industry will undergo rapidly escalating competition from external sources
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While traditional streaming services have undertaken this industry to offer movies and TV shows, the advantage of cable TV plans has been its instant accessibility to live events, such as sports and news. Even this aspect of this industry will be threatened by services, such as YouTube TV, with more than 100 local and cable channels and limitless data storage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The number of US cable TV subscriptions continues its downward spiral
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although the industry has sustained itself by boosting per-customer revenue on premium programming packages, consumers with basic packages have increasingly abandoned cable in favor of alternative services. This spells long-term trouble for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry structure shifts as profit stagnates
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Even as turbulent conditions stemming from the pandemic will largely subside, issues arising before 2020 with the rise of streaming services will challenge this industry. The continued consolidation trend in this industry will accelerate in response to siphoned industry demand. As a reaction, industry enterprise and employment growth will be significantly hindered.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Cable providers look outward for support
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cable providers facing increased competition from Over-the-Top (OTT) services that offer live TV streaming, video-on-demand, and original content without the need for a traditional cable subscription. Providers are responding by partnering with or launching their own OTT services to retain customers and attract cord-cutters.

industry_definition: This industry consists of companies that operate wired, third-party distribution systems for broadcast programming. These operators deliver TV programming received from cable networks or local TV stations to consumers via cable infrastructure on a subscription basis. Cable providers also offer internet access and internet protocol telephony services, usually as a package bundled with a cable TV subscription. This industry excludes telecommunications carriers.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: During the pandemic, many consumers were pushed to use internet-based services and devices to be able to work from home, moving them away from cable providers and toward streaming services. This siphoning of demand has led to reduced revenue and reduced industry profitability.

Cable providers have begun to rely on bundles and other price discounts to remedy the adverse effects of market penetration from streaming services. Prominent companies have taken advantage of these tumultuous times for the industry by acquiring smaller-scale enterprises.

Industry revenue has been hindered as cable TV subscriptions have steadily declined since 2011. Despite this, recent inclines in the number of broadband connections and per capita disposable income, have supported industry demand.

Consumer confidence was depleted in 2020 during the pandemic. This wane in spending made consumers more price-conscious and drove many toward more affordable streaming services instead of cable subscriptions, promoting cord-cutting.

The industry has failed to capture the younger demographic market, as many consumers under 30 have never been subscribed to a cable provider and instead opt toward streaming. To offset this, older consumers over 65 have remained loyal to cable providers despite the emergence of cord-cutting.

Premium channels have surged in popularity as demand for cable content shifts from quantity to quality. This growth has been tempered by many premium channels offering alternative streaming platforms.

Significant vertical integration makes it necessary for major cable providers to expand services in major metropolitan regions like California and New York. Still, suburban and rural subscription rates remain vital revenue sources for cable providers to continually develop service infrastructures.

Comcast announced a partnership with Echo Environmental Holdings LLC. While standard methods of recycling metals in wires have not been successful in the insulation and jacketing of cables, Echo Environmental developed a product that breaks down wires into raw material that can be recycled into new products.

In March 2022, Charter Communications, Inc. announced that it would raise its employees' starting wage to $20.00 an hour. In April 2020, the company increased its wage rates by $1.50 an hour in 2020 and 2021, raising its starting hourly wage from $16.5 to $18.0, respectively. Charter stated that raising starting wages is an important investment in its highly skilled employees.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Older consumers tend to have more established and financially stable households and are more habituated to traditional TV programming.

While streaming has posed a threat to this industry, bundles offered by major players include access to cable and internet services that these companies provide, which is more appealing to consumers aged 50 to 64 as this demographic is more likely to have established households than younger demographics.

Demand from adults under 49 fell somewhat due to the pandemic, as weakening consumer confidence made many consumers more frugal and less willing to spend on cable rather than streaming, which many people view as a less expensive alternative to cable packages.
Commercial markets are essential to the overall business of industry enterprises, even if these markets do not commonly purchase video services.

The younger the consumer is, the less likely they are to subscribe to industry cable services. Part of this may stem from the difficulty among younger generations in establishing their households, a prerequisite for purchasing cable services.

products_and_services.product_description: Nearly three-quarters of industry revenue is generated from selling basic programming packages. This segment is defined as the minimum package of channels offered by any cable provider, so the exact makeup of the segment shifts based on the company.

Premium programming packages include any cable subscriptions that supplement a provider's basic channel offerings. Commonly, these include premium networks, such as HBO or Showtime, which have grown more popular but have also, in some cases, bypassed cable providers through standalone streaming services.
Pay-per-view (PPV) content includes all content sold individually rather than as part of a broader package. Its industry share is somewhat volatile because special events drive it.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Streaming Services Siphon Away Demand from Basic Programming Packages
demand_determinants.determinant_description: With so many consumers paying for content they do not view, the growing number of streaming services, such as Netflix, has created new demand for a la carte channel selection.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Premium Programming Packages Carve Out a Niche
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As the industry loses basic subscribers, it will become more reliant on premium offerings to the households most willing to spend on video content, leading to this segment's share of revenue expanding.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Pay-Per-View Programming Experienced Delays During the Pandemic
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand from this pay-per-view and by extension, its revenue share has shrunk as many live events were postponed or canceled due to the pandemic and social distancing protocols.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the most significant share of establishments out of any region, leveraging its dense population. Cable providers operate near heavily concentrated population centers, where the most demand for their services is.
Vertical integration with content producers is anticipated to shift the concentration of industry establishments more toward the Los Angeles region, where major TV and film networks are located.

Major metropolitan areas like New York are especially vital centers for the industry's most prominent companies since these areas establish corporate headquarters and provide services to a large pool of customers throughout the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Federal regulations are designed to monitor industry ownership and control and restrain potential market dominance, which may otherwise lead to increased cable prices and restrictions on content and program diversity. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) also monitors technological compliance, particularly in general service availability to households and noninterference with other telecommunications signals.

The Cable Communication Act of 1984 established a national policy concerning cable communications and procedures that encourage the development of cable systems and assure that the local community's interests are responded to, including diverse information sources and services. It established guidelines for authorities concerning regulation, established an orderly process for renewal and promoted competition by minimizing regulation. Congress stimulated competition and opened market competition with the 1992 and 1996 Cable Acts.

State and local regulations take a similar form as federal regulations. Some jurisdictions regulate cable TV comprehensively through a state commission or advisory board. In other areas, local governments like city councils regulate cable. These regulatory entities are called local franchising authorities.

Under the Cable Act of 1992, local franchising authorities regulate basic cable and equipment rates. The Act requires that no new cable operator may provide service without a franchise and establishes policies relating to franchising requirements and fees. A local franchising authority may not grant an exclusive franchise and may not unreasonably withhold consent for new service.

Companies in this industry must also follow regulations designed to curb the spread of the pandemic. These workplace regulations, primarily implemented on the state and local level, may include mask mandates, capacity limitations and heightened ventilation standards.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage, increasing barriers to entry.
The industry has a high level of capital intensity, increasing barriers.
There is no industry assistance, keeping barriers steady.
A high level of technology change increases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry faces external competition from alternative entertainment forms, wireless carriers, and streaming content providers.
Cable providers compete on pricing of programming packages, video/audio quality, and customer service.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four players generate nearly half of industry revenue, limiting smaller companies.
Large cable providers pursue vertical integration with cable networks to cut costs.
The industry has consolidated to maintain bargaining power with media conglomerates.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Vertical integration drives purchase costs down
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As the number of cable subscribers increases, so do the programming costs for distributors, limiting the extent to which the industry can minimize this cost segment. Looking toward the future, these costs will dip as industry players, such as Comcast Corporation, become vertically integrated with content suppliers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: As industry automation grows wage costs shift
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Although companies have implemented more automated customer service systems, wage expenses have slightly increased as a share of the revenue. This comes as the industry grows more technical, with enterprises also using customer service as a point of differentiation. In the future, wages will depress as a share of revenue as automated systems become better integrated and industry enterprises increasingly look toward cutting costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: High degree of vertical integration and collaboration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The high degree of vertical integration and collaboration between major cable providers and cable networks presents a challenge to new entrants acquiring the rights to a significant amount of content.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Weak economy as barrier to entry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The weak economy caused by the pandemic has been an additional barrier to entry due to the increased uncertainty, making it difficult for companies seeking to enter the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent additions and innovation concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent additions to the industry is low. This is combined with a low concentration of innovation. Both factors being low suggests that new technology entry is slow and widespread, which limits the threat of disruptive threats hurting leading industry operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Inelastic demand prevents revenue from extremely volatile behavior
volatility_points.volatility_description: This industry's year-over-year revenue changes are slightly indicative of moderate revenue volatility. As evidenced by the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) recent decision to regulate broadband internet service as a public utility, the Cable Providers industry offers some services for which consumers demonstrate highly inelastic demand.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changing consumer preferences orient the industry toward decline
volatility_points.volatility_description: As budget-conscious consumers cut their spending, they have been opting to disconnect their wired phone lines in favor of solely wireless services and cutting their cable in favor of streaming services such as Netflix and Amazon Prime. Declines in both cable subscriptions and wired telecommunications have been mitigated by consumers who purchase bundled services from industry enterprises to save money.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Streaming services siphon away demand from basic programming packages
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nearly three-quarters of industry revenue is generated from selling basic programming packages. The growing number of streaming services, such as Netflix, has created new demand for a la carte channel selection, siphoning away demand from these basic packages.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Premium programming packages carve out a niche
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Premium programming packages include any cable subscriptions that supplement a provider's basic channel offerings, such as premium networks like HBO or Showtime, which have grown more popular but have also bypassed cable providers through standalone streaming services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Pay-per-view programming experienced delays during the pandemic
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Pay-per-view (PPV) content includes all content sold individually rather than as part of a broader package. Demand from this segment has shrunk as many live events were postponed or canceled due to the pandemic and social distancing protocols.

FAQs.question: How have changes in individual consumer electronic use changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: Alternative video platforms have reduced the appeal of traditional cable packages, eroding the industry's customer base.

FAQs.question: Is your company experiencing changes in the type of products and services that customers want?
FAQs.answer: The industry often retains customers by bundling the service with internet and voice, but even these services are declining in relevance. The ongoing rollout of 5G wireless internet is expected to increase the number of consumers using mobile internet as their primary internet source, further reducing the popularity of these bundling packages.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit?
FAQs.answer: As a telecommunications company, the industry must have locations near major population centers.

FAQs.question: How have changes in the technology affected the costs associated with serving your customers?
FAQs.answer: Telecommunication companies must constantly invest in their infrastructure to maintain network quality and reliability. Companies are expected to invest in replacing their aging copper cable infrastructure with fiber-optic cables.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Many traditional TV distributors are currently expanding or exploring online channels. This has reduced demand for cable providers, as many consumers choose to forgo industry services in favor of online options.

FAQs.question: How have software advances altered your company's operations?
FAQs.answer: Customer service functions have been increasingly automated. From now on, wages will be pressured as automated systems become better integrated and the need for employees dwindles.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as Federal Communications Commission (FCC) policy changes?
FAQs.answer: Under the Trump administration, the FCC set restrictions on telecommunications providers, opening the possibility of new revenue streams and increased consolidation. However, the Biden administration is expected to tighten these telecommunications regulations to some extent, which may reduce these opportunities somewhat.

FAQs.question: Are you or your competitors facing scrutiny from antitrust litigation?
FAQs.answer: Historically, mergers within this industry have received much regulatory scrutiny.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your company's customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Customer retention is a key performance metric in this industry, given high customer acquisition costs and service bundling that raises customer value. Economic uncertainty can reduce the percentage of customers that renew their contracts, as consumers pare back their spending in response to difficult economic conditions.

FAQs.question: Profit Margins
FAQs.answer: Profitability varies widely, even among major companies, due to varying network investment requirements and schedules. As overall demand decreased, companies experienced a decline in profitability. The upfront costs of establishing a cable network are significant; however, once the suitable infrastructure is in place, companies that can spread these fixed costs over a large subscriber base can generate a healthy profit. The industry has partially offset subscriber losses through price hikes.

FAQs.question: Cable Network
FAQs.answer: Having an extensive distribution network. Owning and maintaining a well-developed, robust digital cable network enables companies to serve many households and businesses. Industry enterprises pay programming license fees to the cable networks carried and retransmission fees to TV broadcasters. Cable networks often have the upper hand in negotiating these fees. As cable networks have grown to operate more channels, these networks have had greater leverage over cable providers by selling them in bundles.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of new technology? How quickly can you implement new technology into your network?
FAQs.answer: Cable providers must offer the latest interactive cable programming and the fastest internet connections to succeed in this industry. Cable providers deliver video, data, and voice services over the same infrastructure. Technological innovation in any of these fields affects the industry. For example, while the exponential rally in internet traffic has been the primary driver behind the implementation of fiber-to-the-premises networks, fiber-optic networks have also changed how cable providers operate and distribute programming.

FAQs.question: How do you cater to specific demographics? What is your largest customer demographic?
FAQs.answer: Understanding the programming and pricing needs of particular demographics is vital to attracting new subscribers and having a low churn rate among existing subscribers. A lower churn rate among existing subscribers can also help companies in this industry better weather economic uncertainty.

FAQs.question: Do you offer bundled services? How do you compete with external competition?
FAQs.answer: The industry has been experiencing significant external competition, as consumers can now watch TV shows on networks' websites or through online streaming services.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of consumer sentiment? How will you take advantage of an increase in consumer confidence?
FAQs.answer: Changes in consumer sentiment directly affect discretionary expenditure, particularly on high-priced, value-added services. These expenditures slump when economic activity falters because consumers choose to pay down loans, save more and conserve available income for basic needs.

FAQs.question: How will you respond to an increase in the number of broadband connections? Do you currently offer streaming services?
FAQs.answer: In addition to cable TV service, cable providers offer broadband internet access in bundled packages. As the popularity of cable television has declined, bundling packages with broadband internet included with cable television services has allowed companies to bolster their revenue growth.
